result.execSummary:
The defendant Christopher D Brunn was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Court costs are to be paid as a Condition of Probation.
Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling.

No use or possession of illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.
CORRECTED:  The condition of no alcohol is removed.
No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of any and all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent.
No contact with the victims listed in the Criminal Complaint (A.B. AND W.B.) or their residence.

Restitution is ordered payable to the victims as a Condition of Probation and to be paid BEFORE costs/fines/surcharges.
AMENDED 09-08-2016:  Restitution is set at zero ($0).

  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Christopher D Brunn

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Terminated - Regular

Pablo Galaviz appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Christopher D Brunn in court with attorney Patricia M. Padurean.  

State presented statements to the court - victim is not requesting any restitution.
Defense has no objections.
Court orders restitution set at $0.00.

Court also orders a modification of the JOC - removal of the word alcohol from the conditions of probation.
Amended JOC to be filed.
Received and filed in court by the State.
Restitution hearing on September 8, 2016 at 03:30 pm.

District Attorney's Office Law Intern, Grant Scaife appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Christopher D Brunn in court with attorney Patricia M. Padurean.   

State presented their sentencing recommendations.
Defense presented their sentencing recommendations.

Court orders the following:
SENTENCE WITHHELD.


Term of Probation:  1 Year.
CONDITIONS OF PROBATION:  
No Use or Possession of a controlled substances or drug paraphernalia.
No Use or Possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription;
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling 
No contact with:  victim listed in the criminal complaint (A.B. and W.B.) or their residence.

RESTITUTION:  $5,179.80 (to be paid to victims (A.B. and W.B.) - restitution to be paid before costs or fines);
Defense contests the restitution and requests matter be scheduled for a restitution hearing.
Court will hold open restitution until the restitution hearing.


Costs:  $243
To be paid as a Condition of Probation.


Restitution hearing scheduled for September 8, 2016 at 03:30 pm.
Sentencing hearing on July 28, 2016 at 02:00 pm.

Kristi Gordon appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Christopher D Brunn in court with attorney Patricia M. Padurean.   

State moves to amend the Felony to a Misdemeanor.
Defense has no objections.
Amended Information filed.

Defendant enters a Plea of No Contest to the amended charge.
Court finds the defendant Guilty of the amended charge.

Matter put over for Sentencing and Restitution Hearing to the next court date.
